intro: Sida albiflora, commonly known as whiteflower sida, is a flowering plant native to the Americas. It is characterized by its small, white flowers and hairy stems, which are typical features of the Malvaceae family. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in grasslands and open woodlands. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Sida albiflora is also known for its fibrous stems, which have been used in traditional crafts and textiles.
